Constructor Detail

Player

public Player()
You MUST call "super()" in the first line of your constructor. Do NOT rely on the values of Parent, ID, or the thread name in the constructor - due to a limitation in Java they're not set until immediately after creation.

Method Detail

Draw

public void Draw(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                 java.awt.Rectangle ClipRect)
Give the player the option of customizing their team's look. This function may be overloaded by your classes to allow you to draw custom players. Use gc as your graphics constant and draw only in the rectangle provided. The rectangle has the upper X,Y coordinates and the width and height of the area which the player should draw to.

Parameters:
gc - The graphics object.
ClipRect - The part of the object we can draw to

Erase

public void Erase(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                  java.awt.Rectangle ClipRect)
Erases the player's square. You'll probably never need to override this.

Parameters:
gc - The graphics object.
ClipRect - The part of the object we can draw to

run

public void run()
This method must be over ridden to make your players do things. Over ride this function to give the class unique behavior (i.e. make it do something intelligent). When you're looking, use the data member Run to determine when the while loop ends. (see example code)

Specified by:
run in interface java.lang.Runnable
Overrides:
run in class java.lang.Thread

Kill

public final void Kill()
Sets Run to false and provides a way to kill threads

WonPoint

public void WonPoint()
This is called each time your team scores a point. It is particularly useful if your team does any kind of learning.

LostPoint

public void LostPoint()
This is called each time your team is scored against. As with the WonPoint method it is useful for teams that learn or adjust their strategies.

InitializePoint

public void InitializePoint()
This is called at the start of every point. Use it to set up your teams, initialize variables, etc.

GameOver

public void GameOver()
This is called at the end of every game

InitializeGame

public void InitializeGame()
This is called when the team is first loaded. Unlike in the constructor, it is safe to use Parent et al.

CalledPlayer

public final boolean CalledPlayer()
Test for lazy programmers. This function is used to remind programmers that they must call super() in the first line of their contstructor. When the teams are being constructed, it is used to confirm that Player's constructor was called to handle behind the scenes initialization. I doubt that it's foolproof - it's merely a reminder

Returns:
boolean

SetID

public final void SetID(int id)
Give a player a unique number to identify them.

Parameters:
id - The player identification number.

GetBallDistance

protected final int GetBallDistance()
Find out how far away the ball is.

Returns:
int signifying the distance

SetParent

public final void SetParent(World parent)
Keep track of the parent class.

Action

protected final boolean Action(int Act)
The player's actions are returned here. Actually that is slightly misleading - the player makes an action, checks if it is ok and returns that result.

Parameters:
Act - The action the player intends to take.
Returns:
boolean Whether or not it was successful

Look

protected final int Look(int Direction)
Look in the specified direction and see what is there.

Parameters:
Direction - Where to look.
Returns:
int The result of looking.

GetLocation

protected final java.awt.Point GetLocation()
Returns the player's location in X,Y coordinates.

Returns:
Point The player's location.

protected final int FieldX()
Finds out how big the field is horizontally.

Returns:
int The field length.

FieldY

protected final int FieldY()
Finds out how big the field is vertically.

Returns:
int The field height.

GetTeam

protected final int GetTeam()
Find out which team you are.

Returns:
int The team ID number.

GetBallDirection

protected final int GetBallDirection()
Find the direction of the ball.

Returns:
int The ball's direction.

GetOpponentDirection

protected final int GetOpponentDirection(int n)
Find out where opponents are. Since there are four opponents, you feed in a number from 1 to 4 and it will return where that particular one is where 1 is the closest opponent and 4 is the furthest away.

Parameters:
n - Which opponent you want.
Returns:
int The direction of the opponent

GetOpponentDistance

protected final int GetOpponentDistance(int n)
Find out how far away opponents are. This works like the GetOpponentDirection method except that it returns distances.

Parameters:
n - Which opponent you want.
Returns:
int How far away they are.
